G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7\u00a7 2\u20133.proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant pursuant to G.L. c. 223A, §§ 2–3 because Defendant is domiciled in Massachusetts or, alternatively, because Defendant committed a tortious act within the Commonwealth causing injury in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the cause of action arose in Suffolk County, specifically at or near 200 Park Drive, Boston, Massachusetts 02215, and Plaintiff resides in Suffolk County.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.raw_text: *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000) (discussing reasonable care standard).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff was operating the bicycle in a safe, prudent, and lawful manner, following traffic rules, remaining within the marked bike lane, and wearing a protective helmet, consistent with the duties of ordinary care recognized by Massachusetts law. See generally *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000) (discussing reasonable care standard).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.support_reasoning: The opinion in Glidden v. Maglio discusses the elements of negligence and the need to prove breach of a duty of reasonable care and causation in the context of a scaffolding-collapse case. It does not address bicyclists, bike lanes, traffic rules, or helmet use, nor does it articulate any standard specific to those facts. While it generally references the duty to use reasonable care, it provides no authority for the specific proposition that a bicyclist operating as described was acting consistently with Massachusetts duties of ordinary care.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989).”

*Gauvin v. Clark*, 404 Mass. 450, 454 (1.raw_text: *Gauvin v. Clark*, 404 Mass. 450, 454 (1989) (duty of reasonable care).
*Gauvin v. Clark*, 404 Mass. 450, 454 (1.proposition: Defendant’s admission that he was “checking his phone” at or immediately before opening the driver’s side door demonstrates that Defendant was distracted and failed to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances, in violation of the duty to keep a proper lookout and to refrain from unsafe opening of vehicle doors. See, e.g., *Gauvin v. Clark*, 404 Mass. 450, 454 (1989) (duty of reasonable care).
*Gauvin v. Clark*, 404 Mass. 450, 454 (1.support_reasoning: The case does not concern motor vehicle operation, distraction, or door-opening duties. Instead, it narrows the standard of care between co-participants in athletic events to reckless (wilful, wanton) misconduct rather than ordinary negligence or a generic duty of reasonable care. Citing Gauvin v. Clark for the proposition that checking a phone and failing to keep a proper lookout breaches an ordinary negligence duty in a traffic/door-opening context misuses the decision’s holding and subject matter.
*Gauvin v. Clark*, 404 Mass. 450, 454 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that participants in an athletic event owe a duty to other participants to refrain from reckless misconduct and liability may result from injuries caused a player by reason of the breach of that duty…. Precluding the imposition of liability in cases of negligence without reckless misconduct furthers the policy that ‘[v]igorous and active participation in sporting events should not be chilled by the threat of litigation.’”

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B(1) (bicyclists\u2.raw_text: G.L. c. 85, § 11B(1) (bicyclists’ rights and duties similar to drivers of vehicles)
G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B(1) (bicyclists\u2.proposition: At all times relevant, Plaintiff exercised reasonable care for Plaintiff’s own safety and complied with pertinent traffic rules, including Massachusetts laws granting bicyclists the right to use public ways and requiring motorists and occupants of vehicles to exercise due care to avoid collisions. See G.L. c. 85, § 11B(1) (bicyclists’ rights and duties similar to drivers of vehicles); *Mass. Gen. Hosp. v. Grassi*, 356 Mass. 1, 4 (1969) (duty of ordinary care).

*Mass. Gen. Hosp. v. Grassi*, 356 Mass..raw_text: *Mass. Gen. Hosp. v. Grassi*, 356 Mass. 1, 4 (1969) (duty of ordinary care).
*Mass. Gen. Hosp. v. Grassi*, 356 Mass..proposition: At all times relevant, Plaintiff exercised reasonable care for Plaintiff’s own safety and complied with pertinent traffic rules, including Massachusetts laws granting bicyclists the right to use public ways and requiring motorists and occupants of vehicles to exercise due care to avoid collisions. See G.L. c. 85, § 11B(1) (bicyclists’ rights and duties similar to drivers of vehicles); *Mass. Gen. Hosp. v. Grassi*, 356 Mass. 1, 4 (1969) (duty of ordinary care).
*Mass. Gen. Hosp. v. Grassi*, 356 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Mass. Gen. Hosp. v. Grassi deals exclusively with dismissal for lack of prosecution under a municipal court rule and the adequacy of notice of a rule change. It does not concern traffic rules, bicyclists’ rights or duties, motorists’ obligations, or a plaintiff’s exercise of reasonable care for personal safety. Citing this case for a duty of ordinary care in a traffic/bicycling context is therefore inapposite and does not support the stated proposition.
*Mass. Gen. Hosp. v. Grassi*, 356 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, a court, even in the absence of a statute or rule, has discretionary power to dismiss an action which the plaintiff has failed to prosecute with diligence. This is a necessary incident to the right and the duty to keep the judicial system in efficient operation. It is clearly reasonable.”

*O\u2019Hara v. Holy Cross Hospital, Inc.raw_text: *O’Hara v. Holy Cross Hospital, Inc.*, 305 Mass. 186, 187–88 (1940) (duty to look before entering traffic)
*O\u2019Hara v. Holy Cross Hospital, Inc.proposition: The opening of a vehicle door into a lane of travel without first ascertaining that it is reasonably safe to do so has long been recognized as negligent conduct under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., *O’Hara v. Holy Cross Hospital, Inc.*, 305 Mass. 186, 187–88 (1940) (duty to look before entering traffic); *Kaufman v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co.*, 272 Mass. 305, 308–09 (1930) (duty to avoid creating sudden obstruction to others lawfully using way).
*O\u2019Hara v. Holy Cross Hospital, Inc.support_reasoning: This opinion does not discuss the operation of vehicle doors, duties when opening doors into traffic, or any standard of care related to entering a lane of travel. It addresses only whether a default judgment against an absent, nonresident defendant was valid for purposes of proceeding against his insurer. The case is therefore mis-cited for the stated negligence proposition.
*O\u2019Hara v. Holy Cross Hospital, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “But here the so called judgment was one in name and form only. In law it was no judgment at all, but a nullity… Davis, a nonresident of Massachusetts, never submitted himself to the jurisdiction of our courts, and never was served with process here except by leaving a summons at a place that was no longer his residence. A valid judgment was a prerequisite of the present suit; and there was none.”

*Kaufman v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co.*, 27.raw_text: *Kaufman v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co.*, 272 Mass. 305, 308–09 (1930) (duty to avoid creating sudden obstruction to others lawfully using way).
*Kaufman v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co.*, 27.proposition: The opening of a vehicle door into a lane of travel without first ascertaining that it is reasonably safe to do so has long been recognized as negligent conduct under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., *O’Hara v. Holy Cross Hospital, Inc.*, 305 Mass. 186, 187–88 (1940) (duty to look before entering traffic); *Kaufman v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co.*, 272 Mass. 305, 308–09 (1930) (duty to avoid creating sudden obstruction to others lawfully using way).
*Kaufman v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co.*, 27.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Kaufman is a mortgage-foreclosure surplus case and does not concern the operation of vehicles, opening of vehicle doors, traffic safety, or any duty to avoid creating sudden obstructions in a public way. Its reasoning is confined to the rights and remedies of mortgagors and mortgagees in foreclosure sales and surplus recovery at law versus in equity. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about negligent opening of a vehicle door into a lane of travel under Massachusetts law.
*Kaufman v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co.*, 27.relevant_excerpt: "It is our settled law that all that a mortgagee acting under a statutory power of sale can sell by valid sale upon foreclosure is the interest in the property conveyed by the mortgage. ... Upon such a sale the former owner of the equity becomes entitled to any surplus of the amount received from the sale in excess of the amount due upon the obligation secured by the mortgage. This he can recover from the mortgagee by action at law."

*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.raw_text: *Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law on causation)
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.proposition: Defendant’s breach of his duty of care was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and damages. But for Defendant’s negligent conduct in opening his door into the bike lane while distracted and without checking for approaching bicyclists, the collision and Plaintiff’s resulting injuries would not have occurred. See *Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law on causation); *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987) (proximate cause).
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.support_reasoning: The proposition uses Jorgensen to support a straightforward statement of Massachusetts but‑for and proximate causation (that defendant’s negligence in opening a car door into a bike lane was a direct and proximate cause of the collision). Jorgensen does discuss Massachusetts proximate cause and articulates that it requires foreseeability, but‑for causation, and substantial factor. However, the case ultimately finds causation lacking on the specific facts and concerns reputational damages in an airplane accident, not physical injury from negligent operation of a vehicle or dooring of a cyclist. It is therefore a poor fit as authority that a defendant’s negligent act was a direct and proximate cause of a traffic collision; at most it provides the general elements of proximate cause, not support for their satisfaction in circumstances like those described in the proposition.
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, proximate cause requires a showing by the plaintiff, first, that the loss was a foreseeable consequence of the defendant's negligence, second, that the defendant's negligence was a but-for cause of the loss, and third, that the defendant's negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the loss.” 905 F.2d at 535.

*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.raw_text: *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987) (proximate cause).
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.proposition: Defendant’s breach of his duty of care was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and damages. But for Defendant’s negligent conduct in opening his door into the bike lane while distracted and without checking for approaching bicyclists, the collision and Plaintiff’s resulting injuries would not have occurred. See *Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law on causation); *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987) (proximate cause).
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns basic “but for” and proximate cause in a negligence case involving a driver opening a car door into a bike lane. Solimene, by contrast, is a products liability case about whether an employer’s conduct constituted a superseding cause and whether proximate and intervening causation are jury questions. While it discusses proximate and superseding cause generally, it does not articulate or apply the specific ‘but for’ causation principle for a driver’s negligent conduct as claimed in the proposition. Thus, the citation is not a good fit for that specific causal assertion.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.relevant_excerpt: “Generally, questions of causation, proximate and intervening, present issues for the jury to decide. … In McDonald v. Snelling, 14 Allen 290, 296 (1867), we stated that ‘[t]he test is to be found, not in the number of intervening events or agents, but in their character, and in the natural and probable connection between the wrong done and the injurious consequence.’”

*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were a foreseeable and natural consequence of Defendant’s negligence. A reasonable person in Defendant’s position would have foreseen that carelessly opening a vehicle door into a bike lane while checking a phone could cause a bicyclist to collide with the door and fall, resulting in bodily injury and property damage. See *Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978) (foreseeability).
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses foreseeability and proximate cause, holding that an injury is actionable where it is a reasonably foreseeable and natural consequence of the defendant’s negligence. The court explains that an intervening third party’s conduct does not break causation if it was foreseeable, and specifically finds that harm to persons passing through the area (like the plaintiff) from negligent operation of an unsecured vehicle was reasonably foreseeable. This directly supports using the case for the general foreseeability principle applied to a bicyclist doored by a negligently opened car door.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen… The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition… would be operated by unauthorized persons… [and] that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area….”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: In any event, under the comparative negligence statute, any alleged negligence of Plaintiff that is not greater than that of Defendant would merely diminish, and not bar, Plaintiff’s recovery. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; *Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 571, 573–74 (2008).

*Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.*,.raw_text: *Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 571, 573–74 (2008).
*Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.*,.proposition: In any event, under the comparative negligence statute, any alleged negligence of Plaintiff that is not greater than that of Defendant would merely diminish, and not bar, Plaintiff’s recovery. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; *Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 571, 573–74 (2008).
*Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.*,.case_name: Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.
*Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Zinck is a negligence/liquor–liability decision and does not discuss Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, or the effect of a plaintiff’s contributory negligence on recovery. There is no analysis of whether a plaintiff’s negligence less than or equal to a defendant’s merely diminishes rather than bars recovery. Accordingly, the case does not provide authority for the comparative negligence proposition for which it is cited.
*Zinck v. Gateway Country Store, Inc.*,.relevant_excerpt: [No passage in the provided opinion text addresses comparative negligence or G.L. c. 231, § 85; the case focuses on hearsay (statements against penal interest), negligence, and proximate cause in the context of alcohol sales to minors.]

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence is the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under similar circumstances. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); *Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass. 47, 56 (1983).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Jupin discusses the elements of negligence and focuses on duty, foreseeability, and public policy, but it does not articulate the general definition of negligence as the failure to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person under similar circumstances. That formulation appears instead in secondary sources and in Mullins v. Pine Manor College, which Jupin cites for other propositions (jury’s role, foreseeability, duty), not for the basic definition of negligence. Thus, Jupin is not direct authority for the specific negligence definition stated in the proposition.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005). We generally consider the latter three questions — whether a defendant exercised reasonable care, the extent of the damage caused, and whether the defendant’s breach and the damage were causally related — to be the special province of the jury.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence is the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under similar circumstances. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); *Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass. 47, 56 (1983).
*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on proximate cause and foreseeability, not on articulating a general definition of negligence. The only general negligence standard quoted—"that the defendant took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken"—comes via a citation to Cimino and Carey, not as a standalone formulation that negligence is the failure to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person under similar circumstances. Thus, in the portion provided, Mullins does not itself state or develop the claimed general definition of negligence.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[ ] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).”

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that motorists and those in control of vehicles must exercise care for the safety of bicyclists lawfully using the roadway. See G.L. c. 85, § 11B; *Pike v. Guarino*, 488 F.3d 15, 20 (1st Cir. 2007) (applying Massachusetts negligence law to roadway users); *White v. City of Boston*, 363 Mass. 680, 685 (1973) (duty to maintain reasonably safe conditions for lawful roadway users).

*Pike v. Guarino*, 488 F.3d 15, 20 (1st.raw_text: *Pike v. Guarino*, 488 F.3d 15, 20 (1st Cir. 2007) (applying Massachusetts negligence law to roadway users)
*Pike v. Guarino*, 488 F.3d 15, 20 (1st.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that motorists and those in control of vehicles must exercise care for the safety of bicyclists lawfully using the roadway. See G.L. c. 85, § 11B; *Pike v. Guarino*, 488 F.3d 15, 20 (1st Cir. 2007) (applying Massachusetts negligence law to roadway users); *White v. City of Boston*, 363 Mass. 680, 685 (1973) (duty to maintain reasonably safe conditions for lawful roadway users).

*White v. City of Boston*, 363 Mass. 680.raw_text: *White v. City of Boston*, 363 Mass. 680, 685 (1973) (duty to maintain reasonably safe conditions for lawful roadway users).
*White v. City of Boston*, 363 Mass. 680.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that motorists and those in control of vehicles must exercise care for the safety of bicyclists lawfully using the roadway. See G.L. c. 85, § 11B; *Pike v. Guarino*, 488 F.3d 15, 20 (1st Cir. 2007) (applying Massachusetts negligence law to roadway users); *White v. City of Boston*, 363 Mass. 680, 685 (1973) (duty to maintain reasonably safe conditions for lawful roadway users).
*White v. City of Boston*, 363 Mass. 680.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text in this *White v. City of Boston* decision concerns post-conviction procedure and the availability of a motion for new trial to challenge guilty pleas. It does not address roadway safety, duties of motorists, bicyclists, or maintenance of road conditions. Accordingly, as excerpted here, the case does not support the proposition about a duty of care owed to bicyclists using the roadway; the citation appears to be to a different portion or a different case than the one reproduced in this record.
*White v. City of Boston*, 363 Mass. 680.relevant_excerpt: In the present case the judge did not rule on the defendant’s claim that entry of his guilty plea while he was legally incompetent violated his constitutional rights of due process. ... The order denying a new trial is therefore reversed and the case is remanded for consideration of the defendant’s constitutional claims.

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and damages. See *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. at 794–95; *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 547–48 (1982).
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: Payton is a certified-question opinion about Massachusetts tort law on negligent infliction of emotional distress, prenatal injury, wrongful life, and identification/market-share issues; it expressly assumes negligence and causation are not before the court. It does not analyze or decide whether any defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of specific plaintiffs’ injuries, nor does it articulate a general proximate-cause standard in the way the proposition suggests. Thus it does not support the claimed proposition about defendant’s negligence being a direct and proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries and damages.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress." 386 Mass. at 545.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60H (recognizing tor.raw_text: G.L. c. 231, § 60H (recognizing tort damages for pain and suffering).
G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60H (recognizing tor.proposition: Plaintiff also sustained non-economic damages, including physical pain and suffering, emotional distress, mental anguish, inconvenience, and loss of enjoyment of life, all directly resulting from Defendant’s negligent conduct. See G.L. c. 231, § 60H (recognizing tort damages for pain and suffering).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks statutory interest and costs as provided by G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6C, and applicable Massachusetts law, as well as such other and further relief as this Court deems just and proper.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts Rule of Civil Procedure 38 and G.L. c. 231, § 60, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
